Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Atomic, Molecular, and Biological Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the Molecular Physics Laboratory at SRI International provides six undergraduate students each summer the opportunity to participate in research on topics in atomic, molecular and biological physics. In addition to participating in research with an experienced mentor, the REU students will engage in weekly activities such as seminars, ethics training, safety training, and visits to other research laboratories, to ensure not only that their research stays on track but that they have an engaging collegial and scholarly experience. By the end of the program, every student will have presented the results of the work in a thirty-minute seminar.

This REU site will have a number of broader impacts with its focus on providing research opportunities to undergraduates to help prepare them for future science, technology, engineering, and mathematics careers. The site has a strong plan to recruit undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in physics and from non-research institutions. The project is informed by an on-going evaluation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Over the past three summers (2014-2016), the REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Atomic, Molecular, and Biological Physics at SRI International has provided undergraduate students from all over the country a unique opportunity to pursue research in a non-academic setting at one of Silicon Valley’s premier non-profit research institutions. The 18 participants in our program were selected from a pool of over 200 talented applicants. Special emphasis was placed on recruiting diverse groups each summer, with 50% of our participants in the past 3 years being women and 28% of the students being under-represented minorities. The students contributed significantly in advancing the program’s efforts in a variety of research areas including the development of new droplet-based microfluidics techniques to perform numerous biological experiments, hyperspectral imaging for multiplexed cell analysis, the development of mass spectroscopy methods to study plasma biomarkers, novel experiments to study the photochemistry and radical kinetics in aeronomy research, nonlinear optics experiments using stimulated scattering, and in the study of molecular reactions that affect the surfaces of hypersonic flights during their reentry into the atmosphere.

 Each REU student in our program was mentored by a staff scientist in our laboratory and in-depth training was often supplemented with postdoctoral fellows in the laboratory.  Environmental safety personnel and ergonomics specialists were readily available on campus to train the students in lab safety protocols. The students performed research on a small project that was part of a larger research program with the assigned mentor. The students received extensive hands-on training in the aspects of performing research in a laboratory setting, from conceptualizing the problem, to executing experiments, and finally analyzing data and presenting their work to SRI scientists and their peers at a final seminar series. The students also benefitted from several seminars over the summer, given by scientists at SRI International, and invited guest speakers from all over the country. To complement these scientific interactions, the program included visits to industrial, university, and government laboratories in Silicon Valley. Some examples of such activities over the past three summers include visits to the Stanford Linear Accelerator, IBM research labs, Stanford University, and some start-up companies in Silicon Valley, zNano – a company that develops membranes for waste water recovery, and Impossible Foods – a company that develops plant based foods.

Summer research programs for undergraduate students are also a vehicle for the students to decide whether scientific research is a career path they would like to take after graduation. Scientists in our laboratory mentored students on wide ranging career-related topics that included one-on-one sessions with students about what to expect out of a PhD program, lateral career choices in science and engineering after an undergraduate degree, and information on graduate schools. One measure of the success of our program lies in the fraction of our REU students that opt for graduate school. Almost all of our student participants opt for this career path. Our program has helped in developing a qualified STEM workforce by providing training and establishing a strong foundation for research and development in these undergraduates. Over the past three years, we have published 2 peer-reviewed journal publications with former REU students (earlier REU site awards as well as the present one) and we have had local students return over numerous school breaks to interact with their mentors and to finish their summer projects. Key research advances during this three year award that received important contributions from the REU student participants include the development of a droplet based lipid bilayer platform, aeronomy research aimed at measuring the rate constant of H Atom plus Ozone reactions at Mesospheric Temperatures, and the further development of a novel optical scattering based imaging instrument.
